stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream inside Course 14 (working title “Hand-Made Heights”) implementing two set-pieces: a physics-driven paper-airplane ride that has to swoop and land on a pyramid, and a giant rubber-band slingshot that hurls Mario forward.  He also drops into the demo build on real N64 hardware to show recent performance/visual fixes.

development_findings.summary: Paper-airplane object now exists; Kaze is tuning a custom physics loop so the plane loses speed when climbing, gains when diving, and occasionally performs flips before landing on a pyramid.
development_findings.quote: We just kind of need to fudge the equations in a way that we get the result we want.

development_findings.summary: Bug where forward velocity stayed at zero traced to an un-initialised stack value; fixing that produced stable velocity gain/loss.
development_findings.quote: Oh, that's the issue. It was a random value on stack that we used.

development_findings.summary: Plane behaviour depends heavily on angVelPitch; Kaze clamps it at 0x3000 and adds friction to keep motion believable yet chaotic.
Added cardboard paper-target objects off-stream; they now break when hit by Mario’s face.
development_findings.quote: I finished programming the paper targets off-stream. You can now break them with Mario’s face.

development_findings.summary: Created large mechanical Toad NPC that spawns a star once dialogue ends; size and ‘robotic’ text style are deliberate.
Rubber-band slingshot implemented with a simple bone animation in Blender; first frame was being cut by Fast64’s smart-range export, causing mis-alignment.
development_findings.quote: The first animation frame wasn't exporting because there's a smart animation range feature that cuts out all the frames until the first one we have a keyframe on.

development_findings.summary: Demo build now uses the new F3DX3 microcode, giving better RSP performance; occlusion planes and triangle strips are also in use.
development_findings.quote: F3DX3 is in the game, which is a little faster than all the microcodes that existed back then… my game now is RSP-bottlenecked.

development_findings.summary: N64 visual fixes: coverage-multiply-alpha issue causing lines on billboards resolved; option to disable anti-aliasing raises framerate to ~50 FPS in busy areas.
development_findings.quote: You turn it off, you almost get 50 FPS here.

development_findings.summary: Mip-mapping still limited to two levels because Fast64 can’t export more; adding manual display-lists is considered too time-consuming.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distrusts generative AI for actual coding and finds it "absolutely horrendous" right now.
context_findings.quote: AI used to be better at programming, but at the moment it is absolutely horrendous.

context_findings.summary: He is frustrated by chat’s constant questions during unfinished features and sometimes responds bluntly to keep focus.
context_findings.quote: The answer to every single one of your questions so far is just shut up and wait.

context_findings.summary: Believes limited daily hobby time is enough for ROM-hacking, criticising excuses about school/time.
context_findings.quote: School is like six hours a day… you have all the time you want and you're just being a pussy.

context_findings.summary: Birthday is tomorrow; mentions turning older (not 30 yet) and planning a bonus stream.
Marketing: prefers to keep all promotion on his main personal accounts rather than spin up separate ‘game’ socials—until a future original game.
Suspicious that Analogue 3D haven’t offered him a review unit; assumes either product is poor or he’s considered irrelevant.
context_findings.quote: If they're not sending me a review copy… surely there's a reason for that. And surely that means it's garbage.

biobak.summary: Appeared briefly in chat; no specific task discussed in this stream.

zeina.summary: Joined chat near the end; Kaze shows her the finished paper-airplane and rubber-band work.

key_stories.title: Taming the Paper-Airplane
key_stories.summary: Kaze’s attempt to recreate realistic yet fun paper-plane physics kept spiralling into uncontrollable flips or stalled motion.  A hidden bug (garbage stack value) froze velocity, and the interaction between forward speed and angular pitch needed constant tweaking.
key_stories.challenge: Plane either spun endlessly or lost all speed, refusing to follow intended swoop-swoop path.
key_stories.process: Added gravity, clamped angVelPitch, introduced sine-based force, printed debug values, found un-initialised stack variable, iteratively tuned friction and velocity scaling.
key_stories.outcome: Plane now climbs, dives, regains speed, and can be steered to land on the pyramid; backflips optional.
key_stories.key_quote: I didn't think that programming a paper plane was going to be this much of a problem.

key_stories.title: Demo on Real Hardware
key_stories.summary: The public demo is close; Kaze ran it on his N64 to verify fixes: anti-aliasing artifacts removed and performance up thanks to F3DX3 microcode.
key_stories.challenge: Visible lines on billboards and sub-30 FPS in crowded scenes.
key_stories.process: Diagnosed coverage×alpha bug, implemented toggle for AA, updated microcode, and sprinkled occlusion planes.
key_stories.outcome: Visual issues gone and busy areas hit ~50 FPS when AA is off; still minor Z-fighting to address.
key_stories.key_quote: This whole area is basically 60 FPS. Isn’t that nice?
